div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THE Royal P≈øalmi≈øt, filled no doubt with a deep ≈øen≈øe of the divine Goodne≈øs in general, and of the many Mercis-conferred upon him≈øelf in particular, breaks out into this moving language, Come „Äà‚óä„Äâ that fear God, and I will tell you „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ hath done for my Soul.‚ÄîAnd „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ he had for ≈øo doing. Experi
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ daily convinces devout Souls, that nothing has a more immediate tendency to affect them≈øelves, and recommend their glorious and bountifull Benefactor to the choice and adoration
of others, than an artle≈øs, humble Narration of the many Favours, Spiritual or Temporal, which they have received from him, in whom they live and move and have their Being.‚ÄîThis and ≈øuch like con≈øiderations (if I know any thing of my heart) l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ me ≈øome years ago to publi≈øh a ≈øhort Accou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of Gods dealings with me from the time of my Birth to my entering into holy Orde ‚Ä¢ s.‚ÄîAnd as it has plea≈øed a Sovereign God to „Äà‚óä„Äâ that little Tract in a manner I dur≈øt not expect, both at home and abroad. I „Äà‚óä‚óä„Äâ down, „Äà‚óä„Äâ his fear, to fulfill a promi≈øe mad ‚Ä¢ at the end of it, viz. to give a further „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the Lord's dealing with me from that time to my Embarking for America.

div.head: A Further ACCOUNT, &c.
div.p:
HAVING been ordained at Glouce≈øter, on Trinity Sunday 1736, and preached my Sermon on the Nece≈ø≈øity and Benefit of religious Society, to a very crowded Auditory, in the Church in which I was baptized the Lord's Day following, I ≈øet out the next Wedne≈øday to Oxford, where I was received with great Joy by my Religious Friends‚ÄîFor about a Week I continued in my Servitor's Habit, and then took my Degree of Batchelor of Arts, after having been at the Univer≈øity three Years and three Quarters, and going on towards the 22d Year of my Age. My dear and honour'd Friends the Reverend Me≈ø≈ørs. John and Charles We≈øley, being now for ≈øome time embarked for
Georgia, and one or two more having taken Orders, the Intere≈øt of METHODISM, as it was then and is now term'd, had vi≈øibly declined, and very few of this reputedly mad Way were left at the Univer≈øity. This ≈øomewhat di≈øcouraged me at Times, but the Lord JESUS ≈øupported my Soul, and made me ea≈øy by giving me a ≈øtrong Conviction, that I was where He would have me to be‚ñ™ My Degree I ≈øoon found was of Service to me, as it gave me acce≈øs to tho≈øe I could not be free with when in an inferior Station, and as Opportunity offer'd, I was enabled to conver≈øe with them about the Things which belonged to the Kingdom of GOD.‚ÄîThe Sub≈øcriptions for the poor Pri≈øoners (which amounted to about Forty Pounds per Annum) were ≈øoon put into my Hands‚ÄîTwo or Three ≈ømall Charity Schools, maintained by the Methodi≈øts, were under my more immediate In≈øpection, which, with the Time I ≈øpent in following my Studies, private Retirement, and religious Conver≈øe, ≈øweetly filled up the whole of my Day, and kept me from that unaccountable, but too common, Complaint of having any Time hang upon my Hands. The di≈øtributing Money and Books among≈øt
the poor Pri≈øoners, and employing ≈øuch as could work, I found was of admirable Service:‚ÄîFor hereby they were kept from that wor≈øt of Goal di≈øea≈øes, Idlene≈øs; and were not only convinced that we bore a good Will towards them, but al≈øo laid as it were under an Obligation to hear the In≈øtructions we gave them from time to time.‚ÄîThis practice was fir≈øt taken up by the Me≈ø≈ørs. We≈øleys, and would to God all Ordinaries of Pri≈øons would Copy after their good Example‚ÄîThey would de≈øerve well of the Common-wealth, and if actuated by the Love of God, would receive a glorious Reward from him who hath ≈øaid, I was ≈øick and in Pri≈øon, and ye came unto me.

In a ≈øhort Time I began to be more than content in my pre≈øent State of Life. God was plea≈øed to be with me of a Truth,‚ÄîMy Strength was proportioned to my Day, and I had thoughts of abiding at the Univer≈øity, at lea≈øt for ≈øome Years, to fini≈øh my Studies, and do what good I could among≈øt the poor de≈øpi≈øed Methodi≈øts.‚ÄîBut God's Thoughts are not as Man's Thoughts, neither are our Ways as his Ways.‚ÄîBy a Series of unfore≈øeen, unexpected and un≈øought
for Providences, I was called in a ≈øhort Time from my beloved Retirement to take a Journey to the Metropolis of England.‚ÄîWhil≈øt I was an under-Graduate, among≈øt other religious Friends, I was very intimate with one Mr. B‚Äîn, a profe≈ø≈øed Methodi≈øt, who had lately taken Orders, and was Curate at the Tower of London.‚ÄîWith him, when ab≈øent, I frequently corre≈øponded, and when pre≈øent took ≈øweet Councel, and walked to the Hou≈øe of God as Friends. He mention'd me to that late good and great Man Sir John Philips‚ÄîAnd being called down for a while into Hamp≈øhire, he wrote to me to be of good Courage, and in the Strength of GOD, bid me ha≈øten to Town to officiate in his Ab≈øence, and be refre≈øhed with the Sight and Conver≈øation of many who loved me for CHRIST'S ≈øake, and had for a long Time de≈øired to ≈øee me‚Äî

On Wedne≈øday Augu≈øt 4th, (the Pri≈øoners being provided for by the coming of Mr. Harvy, another young worthy Methodi≈øt that had lately taken Deacon's Orders) with fear and trembling I obeyed the Summons, and went in the Stage Coach to London.‚ÄîThere being no other Pa≈ø≈øenger, I employed my≈øelf, a good Part of the Way, in earne≈øt Supplication
to the God of all Grace to be my Guide and my Comforter; at the ≈øame Time I could not help prai≈øing him for changing my Heart and calling me to preach the Go≈øpel at a Place to which, not many Years ago, I would have given much Money, would my Circum≈øtances have permitted, to have went up and ≈øeen a Play. In the Evening I reach'd the Tower, and was kindly received by my dear Friend‚ÄîThe remainder of the Week was ≈øpent in vi≈øiting Sir John Philips, &c. who were too glad to ≈øee me.‚ÄîBut God ≈øent me ≈øomething to balla≈øt it.‚ÄîFor as I pa≈ø≈øed along the Streets many came out of their Shops, admiring to ≈øee ≈øo young a Per≈øon in a Gown and Ca≈ø≈øock. One I remember in particular cryed out, "There's a Boy Par≈øon."‚Äîwhich, as it ≈øerv'd to mortify my Pride, put me al≈øo upon turning that apo≈øtolical Exhortation into Prayer, "Let no Man de≈øpi≈øe thy Youth."

On Sunday Augu≈øt 8th, in the Afternoon I preached at Bi≈øhop-Gate Church, the largene≈øs of which, and the Congregation together, at fir≈øt a little da≈øhed me; but by adverting to God, and con≈øidering in who≈øe Name I was about to ≈øpeak, my Mind was calm'd and I was enabled to preach with
Power.‚ÄîThe Effect was immediate and vi≈øible to all; for as I went up the Stairs almo≈øt all ≈øeem to ≈øneer at me on Account of my Youth; but they ≈øoon grew ≈øerious, and exceedingly attentive, and after I came down ≈øhewed me great tokens of Re≈øpect, ble≈ø≈øed me as I pa≈øs'd along, and made great Enquiry who I was‚ÄîThe Que≈øtion no one could an≈øwer, for I was quite a Stranger. I ≈øpeedily ≈ølip'd thro' the Crow'd, and came to the Tower, ble≈ø≈øing God for his Goodne≈øs to me the unworthie≈øt of the Sons of Men‚Äî

Here I continued for the Space of two Months, reading Prayers twice a Week, catechi≈øing and preaching once, be≈øides vi≈øiting the Soldiers in the Infirmary and Barracks, daily. I al≈øo read Prayers every evening at Wapping Chapel, and preached at Ludgate Pri≈øon every Tue≈øday‚ÄîGod was plea≈øed to give me favour in the Eyes of the Inhabitants of the Tower‚ÄîThe Chapel was crowded on Lord's Days‚ÄîReligious Friends from divers Parts of the Town attended the Word, and ≈øeveral young Men came on Lord's Day Morning, under ≈øerious Impre≈ø≈øions, to hear me di≈øcour≈øe about the New-Birth, and the Nece≈ø≈øity of renouncing all in Affection, in order to follow JESUS CHRIST.

After I had been about a Month in Town, Letters came from the Me≈ø≈ørs. We≈øleys, and the Rev'd Mr. Ingham their Fellow-Labourer, an I≈øraelite indeed, from Georgia. Their Accounts fired my Soul, and made me even long to go abroad for God too‚ÄîBut having no outward call, and being, as I then thought, too weak in Body ever to undertake a Voyage to Sea, I endeavour'd to lay a≈øide all Thoughts of going abroad,‚ÄîBut my Endeavours were all in vain‚ÄîFor I felt at Times ≈øuch a ≈øtrong Attraction in my Soul towards Georgia, that I thought it almo≈øt irre≈øi≈øtible.‚ÄîI ≈øtrove again≈øt it with all my Power, begged again and again with many Cries and Tears, that the Lord would not ≈øuffer me to be deluded, and at length opened my Mind to ≈øeveral dear Friends‚ÄîAll agreed that Labourers were wanted at home, that I had as yet no vi≈øible Call abroad, and that it was my Duty not to be ra≈øh, but wait and ≈øee what Providence might point out to me‚ÄîTo this I con≈øented with my whole Heart, and having ≈øtayed in London till Mr. B‚Äîn came out of the Country, I returned to my little Charge at Oxford, and waited upon my Deacon≈øhip according
to the Mea≈øure of Grace imparted to me

But Oh what a delightful Life did I lead there! What Communion did I daily enjoy with God! And how ≈øweetly did my Hours in private glide away in reading and praying over Mr. Henry's Comment upon the Scriptures! Whil≈øt I am mu≈øing on and writing about it, the Fire I then felt again kindles in my Soul‚ÄîNor was I alone happy‚ÄîFor ≈øeveral dear Youths were quickened greatly, and met daily at my Room to build up each other in their mo≈øt holy Faith‚ÄîGod rai≈øed up Friends for our temporal Support‚ÄîThe late Honourable Betty Ha≈øtings, that Elect Lady, allowed ≈øome of them two or three ≈ømall Exhibitions.‚ÄîI al≈øo partook of her Lady≈øhip's Bounty; and a Gentleman, who≈øe Heart was in an e≈øpecial Manner knit to me when la≈øt at London, was ≈øtirred up, without being ≈øollicited, to ≈øend me not only Money for the Poor, but al≈øo a Sufficiency to di≈øcharge Debts I had contracted for Books before I took my Degree. Upon his Recommendation, I was cho≈øen a corre≈øponding Member of the Society for promoting Chri≈øtian Knowledge, which I rejoiced in, as it gave me an Opportunity of procuring
Books at a cheap and ea≈øy Rate for the poor People.‚ÄîMay the great high Prie≈øt and Apo≈øtle of our Profe≈ø≈øion continue to ble≈øs that Society, and pro≈øper all their pious Undertakings to the Advancement of his own Glory, and his People's eternal Good!

About the Middle of November, Providence once more called me from my beloved, tho' little, Scene of Action.‚ÄîThe Rev'd Mr. Kinchin, now with God, had lately been awakned, and accordingly re≈øolved to a≈ø≈øociate with the de≈øpi≈øed Methodi≈øts, determining to know nothing but JESUS CHRIST and him crucified.‚ÄîHe was then Mini≈øter of Dummer in Hamp≈øhire, and being likely to be cho≈øen Dean of Corpus Chri≈øti College, he de≈øired me to come and officiate for him, till that Affair ≈øhould be decided.‚ÄîBy the Advice of Friends, I went, and he came to ≈øupply my Place at Oxford.‚ÄîHis Pari≈øh con≈øi≈øting chiefly of poor and illiterate People, my proud Heart at fir≈øt could not well brook it.‚ÄîI would have given all the World for one of my Oxford Friends, and mourned for lack of them as a Dove that has lo≈øt her Mate‚ÄîBut upon giving my≈øelf to Prayer, and reading Mr. Law's excellent
Character of O ‚Ä¢ ranius, in his Serious Call to a devout Life, my Mind was reconciled to ≈øuch Conver≈øation as the Place afforded me‚ÄîBefore I came to Dummer Mr. Kinchin had u≈øed his People, according to the Rubrick, to have publick Prayers, twice a Day, viz. In the Morning, it being the Winter Sea≈øon, before it was Light, and in the Evening after the People returned from their Work. He al≈øo catechi≈øed the Lambs of the Flock daily, and vi≈øited from Hou≈øe to Hou≈øe,‚ÄîHe loved his People and was beloved by them‚ÄîI pro≈øecuted his Plan, and generally divided the Day into three Parts, eight Hours for Study and Retirement, eight Hours for Sleep and Meals, and eight Hours for reading Prayers, catechi≈øing, and vi≈øiting the Pari≈øh‚ÄîThe Profit I reaped by the≈øe Exerci≈øes, and conver≈øing with the poor Country people, was ‚Ä¢ n≈øpeakable‚ÄîI ≈øoon began to be as much delighted with their artle≈øs Conver≈øation, as I had been formerly with the Company of my Oxford Friends; and frequently learnt as much by an Afternoon's Vi≈øit as in a Weeks Study‚ÄîDuring my Stay here, an Invitation was ≈øent me to „Äà‚óä„Äâ very profitable Curacy in London: but I
had no Inclination to accept it‚ÄîThe Thoughts of going to Georgia ≈øtill crowded continually in upon me, and at length Providence ≈øeem'd to point my Way thither. About the Middle of December comes a Letter from Mr. B‚Äîn, informing me, that Mr. Charles We≈øley was arrived at London. Soon after came a Letter from Mr. Charles him≈øelf, wherein he informed me, that he was come over to procure Labourers, but added he, "I dare not prevent God's Nomination.‚ÄîIn a few Days after this came, another Letter from Mr. John We≈øley, wherein were the≈øe Words, Only Mr. Delamott is with me, till God ≈øhall ≈øtir up the Hearts of ≈øome of his Servants, who putting their Lives in his Hands, ≈øhall come over and help us, where the Harve≈øt is ≈øo great, and the Labourers ≈øo few. What if thou art the Man Mr. Whitefield? In another Letter were the≈øe Words, Do you a≈øk me what you ≈øhall have? Food to eat, and Raiment to put on, a Hou≈øe to lay your Head in; ≈øuch as your Lord had not; and a Crown of Glory that fadeth not away. Upon reading this my Heart leaped within me, and as it were ecchoed to the Call‚ÄîMany things concurred
to make my Way clear.‚ÄîMr. Ki ‚Ä¢ chin was now elected Dean of Corpus Chri≈øti College, and being thereby obliged to re≈øide at Oxford, he willingly took upon him the Charge of the Pri≈øoners.‚ÄîMr. Harvy was ready to ≈øerve the Cure of Dummer.‚ÄîMr. We≈øley was my dear Friend, and I thought it would be a great Advantage to me to be under his Tuition‚ÄîGeorgia was an Infant, and likely‚ñ™ to be an encrea≈øing Colony; and the Government ≈øeem'd to have its Wellfare much at Heart‚ÄîI had heard many Indians were near, it, and thought it a Matter of great Importance that ≈øerious Clergymen ≈øhould be ≈øent there Retirement and Privacy was what my Soul delighted in.‚ÄîA Voyage to Sea would, in all Probability, not do my Con≈øtitution much hurt: Nay, I had heard the Sea was ≈øometimes Beneficial to weakly People. And ≈øuppo≈øing the wor≈øt, as I mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily return to take Prie≈øt's Orders, it would then be left to my Choice, whether I would fix in my Native Country, or go abroad any more‚ÄîThe≈øe Things being thoroughly weighed, I at length re≈øolved within my≈øelf to embark for Georgia; and knowing that I ≈øhould never put my Re≈øolution into Practice
if I conferred with Fle≈øh and Blood, I wrote to my Relations to inform them of my De≈øign, and withal told them, if they would promi≈øe not to di≈ø≈øuade me from my intended Voyage, I would come and take a per≈øonal leave of them; if otherwi≈øe, knowing my own Weakne≈øs, I was determined to embark without vi≈øiting them at all. A few Days after Mr. Kinchin came to Dummer and introduced Mr.Harvy into the Cure‚ÄîI appri≈øed them of my Intention‚ÄîThey gave me ≈øome friendly Council, and having ≈øpent the beginning of Chri≈øtmas ≈øweetly together, and taken an affectionate leave of the Dummer-People, I returned once more to Oxford, to bid adieu to my Friends, who were as dear to me as my own Soul‚ÄîMy Re≈øolution at fir≈øt a little ≈øhocked them, but having rea≈øon to think, from my Relation of Circum≈øtances, that, I had a Call from Providence, mo≈øt of them ≈øaid, "The Will of the Lord be done."‚Äî

On New-Year's Day 1736,7, I went to Glouce≈øter in order to hear the Bi≈øhop's Opinion, and to take my leave of my Mother and other Relations‚ÄîHis Lord≈øhip received me, as he always did, like a Father,
approved of my De≈øign, wi≈øhed me much Succe≈øs, and ≈øaid He did not doubt but God would ble≈øs me, and that I ≈øhould do much Good abroad. My own Relations at fir≈øt were not ≈øo pa≈ø≈øive‚ÄîMy aged Mother wept ≈øore, and others urged what pretty Preferment I might have, if I would ≈øtay at home‚ÄîBut at length they grew more quiet, and finding me ≈øo fixed, gain≈øayed no longer‚ÄîDuring my ≈øtay here, I began to grow a little Popular. God gave me Honour for a while, even in my own Country‚ÄîI preached twice on the Sabbaths. Congregations were very large, and the Power of God attended the Word; and ≈øome I have rea≈øon to believe were truly converted, who will be my Joy and Crown of rejoicing in the Day of the Lord JESUS.‚Äî

In about three Weeks I went to Bri≈øtol to take leave of ≈øome more of my Relations who lived there. As it was my con≈øtant Practice, go where I would, to attend on the daily publick Offices of the Church, I went, the Thur≈øday after my coming, to hear a Lecture Sermon at St. John's Church. Whil≈øt the P≈øalm was ≈øinging, after Prayers, the Mini≈øter came to my Seat, and asked
me to give the Congregation a Sermon. Having my Notes about me, I complyed. The Hearers ≈øeem'd ≈øtartled, and after Sermon enquiry was made, who I was? The next Day there was another Lecture at St. Stephens. Many crowded thither in Expectation of hearing me again. The Lecturer asked me to preach as the other did the Day before. I again complyed, and the Alarm given here was ≈øo general, that on the following Lord's Day, many of all denominations were obliged to return from the Churches where I preach'd, for want of Room. Afterwards I was called by the Mayor to preach before him and the Corporation. And for ≈øome Time following, I preached all the Lectures on the Week Days, and twice on Sundays, be≈øides vi≈øiting the Religious Societies. The Word, thro' the Mighty Power of God, was ≈øharper than a two edged Sword. The Doctrine of the New Birth and Ju≈øtification by Faith in Je≈øus Chri≈øt (tho' I was not ≈øo clear in it as afterwards) made its way like Lightning into the Hearers Con≈øciences. The Arrows of Conviction ≈øtuck fa≈øt; and my whole Time between one Lecture and another, except what was ≈øpent in nece≈ø≈øary Refre≈øhment,
was wholly taken up in talking with poor Souls under concern. Large offers were made me if I would ≈øtay at Bri≈øtol; and many I believe would have almo≈øt plucked out their own Eyes to have given me! All wondered that I would go to Georgia, who might be ≈øo well provided for at home! And ≈øome urged, if I had a Mind to convert Indians, I might go among≈øt the King's-Wood-Colliers, and find Indians enough. But none of the≈øe Things moved me. Having put my Hand to the Plow, I was determined thro' divine Grace, not to look back. And therefore, at length, I took my leave, but with what mutual Affection and Concern cannot ea≈øily be expre≈ø≈øed.

During my ≈øtay at Bri≈øtol I made a little Elopement to Bath, where I was kindly received by a Dear Friend the Rev'd Mr. Chapman, and ≈øome Elect and honourable Women who befriended the Oxford Methodi≈øts. I preach'd at the Abbey Church twice.‚ÄîThe late Doctor Cockman was plea≈øed to thank me for my Sermon; and Application was made to me by ≈øeveral to print both my Di≈øcour≈øes. But I ≈øcarce allowed ≈øuch a Thought to enter, much le≈øs to lodge within my Heart.

She al≈øo mention'd the Painter, and meeting with him one Night very accidentally, I at length with great Reluctance complied, and endeavoured, whil≈øt the Painter was drawing my Face, to employ my Time, in be≈øeeching the great God by his Holy Spirit to paint his Ble≈ø≈øed Image upon his and my Heart.

Chri≈øtmas now drew near.‚ÄîNotice was given me that the Soldiers were almo≈øt ready to embark for Georgia, Mr. Oglethorp being yet detained, I was re≈øolved to throw my≈øelf into the Hands of God and go with the Soldiers. But the nearer the Time of my Departure approached, the more affectionate and eager the People grew.‚ÄîThere was no end of Per≈øons coming to me under Soul concern. I preached and God ble≈ø≈øed me more and more, and ≈øupported me for ≈øome time with but very little Sleep.

At the Beginning of Chri≈øtmas Week I took my Leave: But Oh what Groans and
Sighs were to be heard when I ≈øaid "Finally, Brethren, Farewell!'. At great St. Helen's, the Cry was amazing. I was near half an Hour going out to the Door. All Ranks gave vent to their Pa≈ø≈øions. Thou≈øands and Thou≈øands of Prayers were put up for me. They would run and ≈øtop me in the Allies, hugg me in their Arms, and follow me with wi≈øhful Looks. Once in the Chri≈øtmas before my Departure, with many others, I ≈øpent a Night in Prayer and Prai≈øe; and in the Morning helped to admini≈øter the Sacrament at St. Dun≈øtans, as I u≈øed to do on Saint's Days‚ÄîBut ≈øuch a Sacrament I never before ≈øaw.‚ÄîThe Tears of the Communicants mingled with the Cup, and had not JESUS given us ≈øome of his New Wine to drink to comfort our Hearts, our parting would have almo≈øt been in≈øupportable. At length December 28th I left London, and went in the Strength of God, as a Poor Pilgrim, on board the Whitaker, after having preached in a good Part of the London Churches, collected about a Thou≈øand Pounds for the Charity Schools, and got upwards of three Hundred Pounds Sterling for the Poor of Georgia among my Friends, for which I have ≈øince publickly accompted.
At the ≈øame Time God rai≈øed me a Sufficiency to ≈øupply my own temporal Nece≈ø≈øities; and gave me repeated Proofs, that if we ≈øeek fir≈øt the Kingdom of God and his Righteou≈øne≈øs, all other Things (I mean Food and Raiment, which is all a Chri≈øtian ≈øhould de≈øire) ≈øhall be added unto us.‚ÄîFor which and all his other unmerited Mercies, I de≈øire to prai≈øe him in Time, and magnify his holy Name, thro' the boundle≈øs Ages of Eternity.

Some particulars that befell me whil≈øt abroad, and how this Tide of Popularity ro≈øe ≈øtill higher at my return home: How I came to commence a Field Preacher, and part with many Friends, who were as Dear to me as my own Soul: How they that would now have plucked out their Eyes and have given 'em unto me, afterwards accounted me their Enemy becau≈øe I told them the Truth: By what Means the Seed now ≈øown ≈øprang up and grew into a great Tree, both in England, Scotland and America: How Divi≈øions aro≈øe among God's People, and what were the Effects and Con≈øequences of them, All this I ≈øay mu≈øt be re≈øerved for another Tract, if God ≈øhould continue my Life and
Strength, and give me Lei≈øure and Freedom to pro≈øecute and fini≈øh it.

In the mean while, let me exhort thee, O Reader, if ≈øerious and a Child of God, to ble≈øs him for what he has done for my Soul: Or if thou art yet in the Gall of Bitterne≈øs, and, thro' Prejudice, thinke≈øt that I have either not told Truth, or wrote out of a vain glorious View, let me only intreat thee to ≈øu≈øpend thy Judgment for a little while, and JESUS ≈øhall decide the Que≈øtion. At His TRIBUNALL we ≈øhall meet, and there thou ≈øhall know what is in my Heart, and what were the Motives which led me out to ≈øuch a publick Scene of Life. At pre≈øent I will trouble thee no more; but beg thee whether ≈øerious or not to endeavour to calm thy Spirit by ≈øinging or reading over the following Lines, tran≈ølated by that Sweet Singer of I≈ørael, and my worthy and Honoured Friend Doctor Watts.

l.hi: MY God, my everla≈øting Hope,
I live upon thy Truth;
Thine Hands have held my Childhood up,
And ≈øtrength'ned all my Youth.
My Fle≈øh was fa≈øhion'd by thy Power,
With all the≈øe Limbs of mine;
And from my Mothers painful Hour,
I've been entirely thine.
Still has my Life new Wonders ≈øeen,
Repeated ev'ry Year;
Behold my Days that yet remain,
I tru≈øt them to thy Care.
Ca≈øt me not off ≈øhould Strength decline,
Or hoary Hairs ari≈øe;
And round me let thy Glory ≈øhine,
When e'er thy Servant dies.
Then in the Hi≈øtory of my Age,
When Men review my Days,
They'll read thy Love in every Page,
In ev'ry Line thy Prai≈øe.

div.p: A BRIEF ACCOUNT OF THE Ri≈øe, Progre≈øs, and Pre≈øent SITUATION OF THE Orphan-Hou≈øe, in Georgia.
IN A LETTER TO A FRIEND.
By George Whitefield, A.B Late of Pembroke-College, Oxon.

q.hi: Provide Things hone≈øt in the Sight of all Men.

div.p: PRINTED IN THE YEAR, 1740.

div.head: BRIEF ACCOUNT, &c.
div.p:
IT being now ≈øome Months ≈øince I arrived here, I think it high time, according to my Promi≈øe, to ≈øend you as explicite an Account a ‚Ä¢ I well can, of the Ri≈øe, Progre≈øs and Pre≈øent Situation of the Orphan-Hou≈øe, where I now am.‚ÄîSome have thought that the erecting ≈øuch a Building was only the Produce of my own Brain: But they are much mi≈øtaken. For it was fir≈øt propo≈øed to me by my dear Friend the Rev'd Mr. Charles We≈øley, who with his Excellency General Oglethorp, had concerted a Scheme for carrying on ≈øuch a
De≈øign before I had any Thoughts of going abroad my≈øelf. It was natural to think, that as the Government intended this Province for the Refuge and Support of many of our poor Countrymen, that Numbers of ≈øuch Adventurers mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be taken off, by being expo≈øed to the Hard≈øhips which unavoidably attend a new Settlement. I thought it therefore a noble De≈øign in the General to erect a Hou≈øe for fatherle≈øs Children. And believing ≈øuch a Provi≈øion for Orphans would be ≈øome Inducement with many to come over, I fell in with the De≈øign, when mention'd to me by my Friend, and was re≈øolved, in they Strength of God, to pro≈øecute it with all my might.‚ÄîThis was mention'd to the Honourable the Tru≈øtees. They took it kindly at my Hands; and as I then began to be pretty popular at Bri≈øtol, and el≈øe where, they wro ‚Ä¢ e to the Bi≈øhop of Bath and Wells, for leave for me to preach a Charity Sermon on this Occa≈øion in the Abby Church. This was granted, and I accordingly began immediately to compo≈øe a ≈øuitable Di≈øcour≈øe. But knowing my fir≈øt ≈øtay at Georgia would nece≈ø≈øarily be ≈øhort, on account of my returning again to take Prie≈øt's Orders, I
thought it mo≈øt prudent fir≈øt to go and ≈øee for my ≈øelf, and defer pro≈øecuting the Scheme till I came home; becau≈øe I could then be better able to judge, whether the Scheme was practicable, and con≈øequently could be able to recommend it with the greater Earne≈øtne≈øs.‚ÄîWhen I came to Georgia I found many poor Orphans, who, tho' taken Notice of by the Honourable Tru≈øtees, yet thro' the Neglect of Per≈øons that acted under them, were in mi≈øerable Circum≈øtances.‚ÄîFor want of a Hou≈øe to breed them up in, the poor little Ones were tabled out here and there, and be≈øides the Hurt they received by bad Examples, forgot at home what they learnt at School.‚ÄîOthers were at hard Services, and likely to have no Education at all.‚ÄîUpon ≈øeeing this, and finding that his Maje≈øty and Parliament had the Intere≈øt of this Colony much at Heart, I thought I could not better ≈øhew my regard to God and my Country, than by getting a Hou≈øe and Land for the≈øe Children, where they might learn to labour, read and write, and at the ≈øame Time be brought up in the Nurture and Admonition of the Lord.‚ÄîAccordingly at my return to England, in the Year 1738, to take
Prie≈øts Orders, I applied to the Honourable Society for a grant of 500 Acres of Land, and laid my≈øelf under an Obligation to build a Hou≈øe upon it, and to receive from Time to Time as many Orphans as the Land and Stock would maintain. As I had always acted like a Clergyman of the Church of England, having preached in a good Part of the London Churches, and but a few Months before collected near a Thou≈øand Pounds Sterling, for the Children belonging to the Charity Schools in London and We≈øtmin≈øter; it was natural to think, that I might now have the U≈øe at lea≈øt of ≈øome of the≈øe Churches to preach in for the Orphans hereafter more immediately to be committed to my Care.‚ÄîBut by that time I had taken Prie≈øts Orders, the Spirit of the Clergy began to be much imbittered.‚ÄîChurches were gradually denied me‚ÄîAnd I mu≈øt let this good De≈øign drop, and Thou≈øands (I might add ten Thou≈øands) go without hearing the Word of God, or preach in the Fields.‚ÄîIndeed two Churches one in London, viz. Spittle-fields, and one in Bri≈øtol, viz. St. Philips and Jacob, were lent me upon this Occa≈øion; but tho≈øe were all.‚ÄîHowever, God kept me from being
di≈øcouraged.‚ÄîI collected for the Orphan-Hou≈øe in Moor-fields, Two and Fifty Pounds one Sabbath Day Morning; Twenty Two Pounds of which was in Copper. It would have rejoiced your Heart to ≈øee the People give.‚ÄîThey offered willingly, and took more pains to come through the crowd and put their Contributions into my Hatt, than ≈øome would to have got them.‚ÄîThou≈øands of Prayers were put up with the Alms that were given, and I tru≈øt both went up as a Memorial before God. In the Afternoon I collected again at Kennington Common, and continued to do ≈øo at mo≈øt of the Places where I preached. Be≈øides this, two or three of the Bi≈øhops, and ≈øeveral Per≈øons of Di≈øtinction contributed, till at length, having gotten about a Thou≈øand and ten Pounds, I gave over collecting, and went with what I had to Georgia. At that time multitudes offered to accompany me; but I cho≈øe to take over only a Surgeon and a few more of both Sexes, that I thought would be u≈øeful in carrying on my De≈øign. The≈øe chearfully embarked with me, de≈øiring nothing for their Pains, but Food and Raiment, My Dear Fellow-Traveller, William Seward, E≈øq; al≈øo joined with them,
and was particularly u≈øeful to me on this Occa≈øion. Our fir≈øt Voyage was to Philadelphia, where I was w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing to go for the ≈øake of laying in Provi≈øion. Having a Captain of a Ship with me, who had been my ≈øpiritual Child, by his Advice, I laid out in London a good Part of the Thou≈øand Pounds for Goods; and by his Care and my other Fellow-Travellers, without any trouble to my≈øelf, got as much by them at Philadelphia as nearly defrayed the Family's Expence of coming over. Here God ble≈ø≈øed my Mini≈øtry daily, and begun that Work in Philadelphia, which, I am per≈øuaded, will be remembred thro' the Endle≈øs Ages of Eternity. January following 1739 I met my Family at Georgia, and being unwilling to lo≈øe any time, I hired a large Hou≈øe, and took in all the Orphans I could find in the Colony, A great many al≈øo of the Town's Children came to School gratis, and many poor People that could not maintain their Children, upon Application, had leave given them to ≈øend their little ones for a Month or two, or more, as they could ≈øpare them, „Äà‚óä„Äâ at length my Family con≈øi≈øted of between 60 and 70. Mo≈øt of the Orphans were in poor Ca ‚Ä¢ e, and three or four almo≈øt
eat up with Lice‚ÄîI likewi≈øe erected an Infirmary, in which many ≈øick People were cured and taken care of Gratis. I have now by me a Li≈øt of upwards of a Hundred and Thirty Patients, which were under the Surgeon's Hands, exclu≈øive of my own private Family. This Surgeon I furni≈øhed with all proper Druggs and Uten≈øils, which put me to no ≈ømall Expence: And this was ≈øtill increa≈øed by clearing Land, buying Stock, and building a large Dwelling Hou≈øe Sixty by Forty, and Out Hou≈øes, commodious for a large Family to live in. Sometimes (Labourers and all) I have had a Hundred and Twenty to provide for daily‚ñ™ My Friends as well as my≈øelf, ≈øeem'd to have particular Courage and Faith given us for the Sea≈øon; and we went on chearfully, believing that he for who≈øe ≈øake we began, would enable us to fini≈øh this good Work. About March I began the great Hou≈øe, having only about One Hundred and Fifty Pounds in Ca≈øh. I called it Bethe≈øda, becau≈øe I hoped it would be a Hou≈øe of Mercy to many Souls. Ble≈ø≈øed be God we have not been di≈øappointed of our Hope. It has proved a Hou≈øe of Mercy indeed to many.
Several of our Labourers, as well as Vi≈øitors, have (in a Judgment of Charity) been born of God here, and given evident Proofs of it, by bringing forth the Fruits of the Spirit. Many Boys have been put out to Trades, and many Girls put out to Service. I had the Plea≈øure the other Day of ≈øeeing three Boys work at the Hou≈øe in which they were bred, one of them out of his Time a Journeyman, and the others ≈øerving under their Ma≈øters. One that I brought from New-England is hand≈øomely ≈øettled in Carolina; and another from Philadelphia is married and lives very comfortably at Savannah. How ≈øo large a Family has been ≈øupported in ≈øuch a Colony, without any vi≈øible Fund, is wonderful! I am ≈øurprized when I look back, and ≈øee how for the≈øe ≈øix Years la≈øt pa≈øt, God has ≈øpread a Table in the Wilderne≈øs for ≈øo many Per≈øons. Were all the particular Providences that have attended this Work recorded, perhaps they would be found not inferior to tho≈øe mentioned by Profe≈ø≈øor Frank, in his Pietas Ha ‚Ä¢ len≈øis, who≈øe Memory is very precious to me, and who≈øe Example has a Thou≈øand Times been ble≈ø≈øed to ≈øtrengthen and encourage me in the carrying on this Enterprize.
Hereafter perhaps when I have more Lei≈øure, I may give you an Account of ≈øome of them‚ÄîMy being detained ≈øo long in England has been a little detrimental to me, my Friends not knowing ≈øo well how to act, becau≈øe they expected to ≈øee me daily. And I cannot yet ≈øay that I have ≈øurmounted the fir≈øt Years Expence, which indeed was very great, and greater no doubt than it would be now, after my Friends have had ≈øo many Years Experience in the Colony.‚ÄîHowever I doubt not but by the Ble≈ø≈øing of God, in a ≈øhort Time to pay off my Arrears, and then the Family will be maintained at a ≈ømall Expence.‚ÄîMy ≈øtanding Annual Charges, are now but trifling to what they have been; and my Friends have rai≈øed an annual Sub≈øcription ≈øufficient for di≈øcharging it till the Family may be able to provide for it≈øelf.‚ÄîThis, God willing, I hope will be, in a good Mea≈øure, ≈øpeedily effected. We have lately begun to u≈øe the Plow; and next Year I hope to have many Acres of good Oats and Barley. We have near twenty Sheep and Lambs, Fifty Head of Cattle, and Seven Hor≈øes. We hope to kill a Thou≈øand Weight of Pork this Sea≈øon. Our Garden which is
very beautiful, furni≈øhes us with all Sorts of Greens, &c. We have plenty of Milk, Eggs, Poultry, and make a good deal of Butter weekly. A good Quantity of Wool and Cotton has been given me, and we hope to have ≈øufficient ≈øpun and wove for the next Winter's Cloathing.‚ÄîIf the Vines hit, we may expect two or three Hog≈øheads of Wine out of the Vineyard. The Family now con≈øi≈øts of Twenty Six Per≈øons. Two of the Orphan Boys are blind, one is little better than an Idiot.‚ÄîBut notwith≈øtanding they are u≈øeful in the Family, the one in the Field and the other in the Kitchen. I have two Women to take Care of the Hou≈øhold Work, and three Men and two Boys employed about the Plantation and Cattle. A ≈øet of Dutch Servants has been lately ≈øent over: The Magi≈øtrates were plea≈øed to give me two; and I took in a poor old Widow, aged near 70, whom no body el≈øe cared to have. A valuable young Man from New-England is my School-Ma≈øter, and in my Ab≈øence performs Duty in the Family. On Sabbaths the grown People attend on publick Wor≈øhip at Savannah, or at White-bluff, a Village near Bethe≈øda, where a Dutch Mini≈øter officiates
My dear Friends who have hitherto been my A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, being married and having each one or two Children, thought it be≈øt, as mo≈øt ≈øuitable to the In≈øtitution, to remove. God has mercifully provided for them, and they are comfortably ≈øettled, ≈øome at Savannah and ≈øome el≈øewhere. We frequently write to and hear from one another. I need not trouble you with the Order of our Family. It is pretty near the ≈øame as u≈øual, and I do not think to make any material Alteration for ≈øome time. Many have applied to me to take in their Children as Boarders, and erect a publick School: But I have not yet determined. It is certain ≈øuch a School would be exceeding u≈øeful in this part of the World, if there ≈øhould be a Peace, not only for tho≈øe northern Parts of the Colony, but al≈øo for the more Southern Parts of Carolina, Purisburgh, and Frederica, where are many fine Youths. I have been prevailed on to take one from Frederica, and another from Puri≈øburgh, and it may be ≈øhall admit more. For the pre≈øent, con≈øidering the Situation of Affairs, I think it mo≈øt prudent to go on in making what Improvements I can on the Plantation and bring a Tutor with me
from the Northward in the Fall, to teach a few Youths the Languages, and enlarge the Family when Affairs are more ≈øettled. The Hou≈øe is a noble commodious Building, and every Thing ≈øweetly adapted for bringing up Youth. Here is Land to employ them in to exerci≈øe their Bodies, and keep them from ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ene≈øs out of School Hours. Here are none of the Temptations to debauch their tender Minds, which are common to more populous Countries, or in Places where Children mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be brought up with Negroes. What God intends to do with the Colony is not for me to enquire: Secret Things belong to him. It has hitherto been wonderfully pre≈øerved, and the Orphan-Hou≈øe, like the burning Bu≈øh, has flouri≈øhed uncon≈øumed. In fine, the Government has, no doubt, its Wellfare much at Heart: And, God willing, I intend to carry on my De≈øign till I ≈øee the Colony ≈øink or ≈øwim. The Money that has been expended on the OrphanHou≈øe, and Orphan-Hou≈øe Family, has been of va≈øt Service to this Northern Part of the Colony. And tho' it has been greatly detrimental to my own private Intere≈øt, yet I do not repent of the Undertaking‚ñ™ No, I
rejoice in it daily, and hope yet to ≈øee many more Souls born unto God here. I have had a very comfortable Winter. The People of Savannah, having no Mini≈øter till lately, gladly accepted my Labours; and at Frederica, the Gentlemen and Soldiers of General Oglethorp's Regiment, as well as the Inhabitants of the Town, received me very gladly. Major Horton ≈øeems to behave very well. He has a very fine growing Plantation‚ÄîI ≈øaw Barley in the Ear the fir≈øt of March. Georgia is very healthy‚ÄîNot above one, and that a little Child, has died out of our Family, ≈øince it removed to Bethe≈øda. I think the Colony (were the Inhabitants ≈øufficiently numerous) is as capable of as good Improvement as any on the Continent.

For the Satisfaction of my Friends, and ≈øilencing, if po≈ø≈øible, my Enemies, I have had my Accounts from the very Beginning to January la≈øt, publickly audited and examined, Debittor and Creditor, Article by Article; and an Oath for Confirmation, being an End of all Strife, I have ≈øworn to them. A Copy of the Audit, with the particular Names of the Children, I have annexed hereunto. If it gives you or others
any Satisfaction I ≈øhall be glad. I have no more to add, but to beg a continued Intere≈øt in your Prayers, and ≈øub≈øcribe my≈øelf,

closer.signed: Your Mo≈øt affectionate Friend, and Servant, George Whitefield.

div.p: THIS Day per≈øonally appeared before us, Henry Parker and William Spencer, Bailiffs of Savannah afore≈øaid, William Woodr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ffe, William Ewen, and William Ru≈ø≈øel, of Savannah afore≈øaid; who being duly ≈øworn, ≈øay, That they have carefully and ≈øtrictly examined all and ≈øingular the Accounts relating to the Orphan Hou≈øe, in Georgia, contained in Forty one Pages, in a Book intitled, Receipts and Di≈øbur≈øements for the Orphan Hou≈øe in Georgia, with the original Bills, Receipts, and other Vouchers, from the Fifteenth Day of December, in the Year of our Lord One Thou≈øand Seven Hundred and Thirty Eight, to the Fir≈øt Day of January, in the Year of our Lord One Thou≈øand Seven Hundred and Forty Five; and that the Monies received on Account of the ≈øaid Orphan Hou≈øe, amounted to the Sum of Four Thou≈øand, Nine Hundred, Eighty Two Pounds, Twelve Shillings, and Eightpence, Sterling, as above; and that it doth not appear that the Reverend Mr. Whitefield hath converted any Part thereof to his own private U≈øe and Property, or charged the ≈øaid Hou≈øe with any of his travelling, or other private Expences; but on the contrary, hath contributed to the ≈øaid Hou≈øe many valuable Benefactions; and that the Monies di≈øbur≈øed on Account of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, amounted to the Sum of Five Thou≈øand, Five Hundred, Eleven Pounds, Seventeen Shillings, and Ninepence Farthing, Sterling, as above; which we, in Ju≈øtice to the Reverend Mr. Whitefield, and the Managers of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, do hereby declare, appear to us to be faithfully and ju≈øtly applied to and for the U≈øe and Benefit of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe only.
